Surprisingly fun - a lot of the negative reviews are quite misleading, possibly becuase they did not play enough to find all of the game's features.  The game stands out as unique in the MOBA genre by having 4 teams rather than 2, and it works quite well.  The game is designed around this 4 team system rather than having it thrown on just to make the game different, which means that the win conditions, map, and pacing of the game aren't as similar to standard MOBAs as you might expect.  Rather than winning by destroying a structure as in most MOBAs, your team needs to be the first to collect 30,000 gold.  Games are quite fast, lasting 15-20 minutes on average, and are fast paced all the way through.

In this game's case, it makes more sense to talk about the problems that the game has before talking about what it does right, as of some of the features available lessen the impact of many of the problems.

CONS
1. Pay to win

A lot of the p2w" features such as legendaries are earnable in-game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Golden Rush has a fair number of 'new' mechanics for a moba game. such as full rpg equipment drops in-game ranging from normal-set items. Obviously the 4 player mode is also a different change of pace from mainstream mobas, but lacks the same smooth charm as Deep Silver's Dead Island Epidemic.

The game is still quite unpolished. The skills of the current playable champions are subpar and unbalanced. Certain AoE ultimates that cast at the drop of a hat- .5, while other level 1 skills take upwards of ,75-1 to cast. Random creep camps spawn with elite mobs that aoe 2/3 of your life on death, makes farming a bit rediculous at times. Then there is the golden frog- a nice little addition- if only the pathing of it was fair. Some games the frog simlpy dances around one side of the map giving teams on that side a grossly  unfair gold advantage.
Taking towers are also a pain, as every time an enemy sets foot into the cap circle, the capture is reset until the enemy leaves. It also either appears that the number of players do not affect capture speed or give such a negligible buff that teamates are better off defending the circle while 1 teamate captures. This makes capturing towers immensely difficult and annoying. Then there are the checkpoint portals, which would have been a neat addition, had it not been placed directly on top of creep camps, making them inaccesible most of the time. They are also randomly spawned, but certain locations also need rebalancing and give certain sides heavy advantage.

The UI needs work, a lot of work. There is guide or list of commands. You're left to figure everything out yourself, search the forums, or ask other players. Too bad 60% of the players don't speak english and the lobby chat doesn't appear to be working, but at least they do have an option to open the forums through the game.

Overall it's a game that is attempting new things, but there are many kinks that still need to be worked out. If you're looking for something new or were a fan of DI: Epidemic, it might be worth your time to check out this game.
I would recommend friends to try it themselves as it is a small download, but I wouldn't play it again until they start rebalancing the heroes and the checkpoint portals.

Honestly, this is the WORST MOBA I've ever played and I've played pretty much all of them.  Imagine League of Legends Dominion mode mixed with Diablo 3.  Items are PERMANENT and the matchmaking does not seem to take that into account.  Meaning, if you're starting out in this game, you have close to zero chance of winning since half the other players start with more health and damage than you'll have at max level.
To make matters worse, there are also four consumables that you basically must have to have any chance at victory and the best consumables are for a paid currency.  You do get a small amount of this currency after the game, but unless you placed first (highly unlikely until you've shelled out 500$ or played for 1000 hours) you won't get enough to refresh your consumables. This makes the game go in a horrible spiral of Lost a match. Either I lose the next one too or drop 5$ for a chance to win. Lost again." and so on.
This game is clearly a money grabbing scheme shrouded with the concept of "well you 'can' just play the game forever and get everything." but that's not realistic when it's nigh impossible to actually contribute to a win without dropping a lot of money."

I would not recommend this game at all. There are too many things that skew the balance of the game. Not only that, this game is pay-to-win. You have 2 12-player maps, Dragons' Lair and Garden of Heroes, where you are divided into teams of 3 to complete a winning objective.

In Dragons' Lair, you have to collect 12 gold chests. I couldn't play this one as there weren't enough players.
In Garden of Heroes, you have to be the first to 30,000 gold. You capture Gold Towers, kill heroes and creeps and find gold chests to get the 30,000 gold.

Forbes Consult Ltd/Elyland (This is the developer) didn't really make a quality game. It was more of a Diablo grinder in the hope that you would get addicted and spend cash to improve your hero. I rate Elyland very lowly as a game developer.

PROS
1. Good First Effort
It looked good until I played it.

2. Graphics
Nice hero models.

CONS
1. Pay To Win
I captured screenshots of the exchange rate and it was totally ridiculous.

2. Item Shop Level
To get higher level items, you have to upgrade your shop level. You'll start off at Shop Level 2 and it can keep on going higher. You have to get more Prestige to upgrade your shop. This skews the advantage to players who have a higher shop and better items.

3. Abilities
Only 3 spells to press QWE. The ultimate is hidden and has to be unlocked by finding artifact items and transmuting them. This is extremely horrible.

4. Inventory System
Similar to Diablo's slot system where you have a torso, weapons, head, neck and feet slots. I liked it at first since I thought it wasn't going to affect gameplay and was purely cosmetic. However, that wasn't the case.

Your items give you stats, similar to Diablo, and since they can be bought with cash, you can buy an advantage. Thus, proof of pay-to-win.

NEUTRAL
1. Heroes
Only 6 heroes at the moment. First 3 are free, others are DLC. Okay to view, but they are very generic and bland. The mage looked interesting though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On a first note, i haven't given up - yet. Even though a gave it a bad rating. Why? read on, there's actually a hidden (black) gem in this game; it's just not for free.
Lets get one thing straight, this game introduces a new kind of game mode which is actually quite refreshing. 4 teams? Genius.
The RPG element where you equip your character in between games is fun - you can either buy items in the shop when not in-game or you can find it during a game. Potions are also limited, which makes for strategic use.

However, there are a few minor problems with this game. And when i say minor, i actually mean this is pay2win or being massochistic till you actually make it.

Let me break it down.

Heroes
There are 3 free heroes, the other 3 you can buy. The free heroes are far from bad, but the paid ones seem slightly better. Not a very big problem, because you can earn points to unlock said heroes. You earn points by winning or placing 2nd in a game.

Items
Here is the reall kicker, there are different item sets; normal, special and legendary (or something like that). You can either buy them in the shop or find them during your games. The ones you'll really be looking for are the green ones, the legendary items. If you buy those in the shop, black gems instead of gold. (Black Gems are the equivalent of real-life money.) But even if you find something green, you have to transmute it, at the cost of your black gems, to keep it.
Green items are significantly better than other items. Not only give they better bonusses, but when you own a complete set, it'll unlock another skill.

The problem
As stated before, if you have what it takes, you can unlock everything for free. And if you have the time and patience, i'm sure you can do it. But. But, if you want to stand a chance to unlock everything, you'll need to end up being 1st or 2nd very very often.
If the games where balanced, this would actually be a fun challenge. But they're not - unless you and your team have legendary gear, you stand no chance of winning, because there's always another team that does.
And there it is, pay2win at its finest; deluding you into trying to do it all for free, only to frustrate you enough to give up and give in.
